awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a Flow Cytometer Cell Sorter for Multidisciplinary Studies at Oakland University
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Oakland University to acquire a Fluorescence-Activated Cell Sorting (FACS) machine to support and enhance multidisciplinary research and educational programs at the institution. The FACS machine will allow undergraduate/graduate students and faculty to participate in research and educational activities that will enhance the mission of the Departments of Biological Sciences and Chemistry as well as the Eye Research Institute. Specifically, the FACS machine will allow for hands-on collaborative research in the areas of amphibian biology, cancer biology, chemistry, DNA repair, developmental biology, immunology, molecular biology, plant genomics, and stem cell biology.  The instrument will be incorporated into the science and bioengineering curriculums, as part of teaching laboratories and design projects, and will allow for new course development. This instrument will also allow for student and faculty recruitment and provide a sophisticated service technology to the surrounding region.

Flow cytometry combined with cell sorting enables characterizing, defining and sorting of different cell types and subpopulations by analyzing the expression of cell-surface and intracellular molecules.  Among some specific projects in which this instrument will be used are the determination of basic biological functions and signaling directed by cell surface proteins in stem cells, the role of endothelial cells on anti-apoptotic pathways, the regulation of pre-mRNA processing in plants, the effects of temperature in amphibian immunology, the development of tubular organs, and basic understanding of DNA repair mechanisms.  Results from the research using the instrument will be disseminated in peer-reviewed publications, scientific meeting and to the community throughout outreach activities in which faculty of this institution participate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This funded proposal supported the acquisition of a flow cell sorter instrument to support and enhance multidisciplinary research and education programs in the departments of Biological Sciences, Chemistry, and the Eye Research Institute at Oakland University.  Flow cytometry is a powerful technique that allows the characterization of cells and particles within a population by analyzing the expression of proteins localized outside and inside of cells.  With this technique, one can identify and categorize subpopulations within a larger population of cells or particles, and obtain data regarding the quality and quantity of individual units and groups.  Flow cytometry combined with sorting is even more powerful, as individual cells or groups of cells with specific characteristics can be recovered after the flow cytometry characterization and analysis.  In this way, a population of cells can be subcategorized and those groups can be recovered for further downstream analysis, which can include further cell expansion, genetic analysis, and cell transplantation, among others.  

With the acquisition of this instrument, professors, researchers, and students at Oakland University and neighboring institutions are able to advance their research capabilities in multiple disciplines ranging from studies of cancer ad stem cell biology to immunology of amphibians.  Data generated using this instrument and flow cell sorting was used in publications in high-impact scientific journals, oral and poster presentations in local, national, and international scientific meetings, which until now and together are close to be around thirty.  Furthermore, data obtained from this instrument has been used to support research funded by other federal agencies and organizations supporting investigators, such as NSF, NIH, NASA, and AHA.  Similarly, data generated with this instrument is used to support preliminary findings to be used in grant proposal applications.   

The number of users of the instruments has increased significantly during the three years of support and we predict that will continue to grow during the useful life of the instrument.  Initially, was mainly used by the group of researchers supporting this application, however, soon after other researchers took advantage of the benefits that this instrument brings to their research.  While initially the instrument will be used twice a month during the first year by year three its use was every other day.  The demographics of users -around 40- of this instrument range from assistant professors to full professors, from undergraduate and graduate students to post-doctoral fellows, including researchers from neighboring institutions.  Among the users are people from underrepresented minorities and women. 

The acquisition of this instrument supported the formation of a Flow Cytometry Core Facility in the Department of Biological Sciences that provided service to the above-described multidisciplinary users with a pay-per-service system to promote the sustainability of the instrument for a long period after the grant support period ends.  In addition, the acquisition of the instrument promoted the formation of highly qualified operators.  Until this moment, two graduate students and one post-doctoral fellow have been operators of this instrument and they have gained significant experience and provided quality services to dozens of users.  The users work closely with the operators in the design, planning, and preparation of the samples and get knowledge of the proper use of this instrument.  This system is implemented to maximize the long life of the instrument and resources to obtain valuable data from it. 

The broader impact of this instrument is reflected in the multidisciplinary user from the departments of Biological Sciences, Chemistry, the Eye Research Institute, the Medical School, and neighboring institutions, which now have direct and affordable access to cell sorting capabilities.  The acquisition of the flow cell sorter complemented an array of equipment required to perform research at levels that are competitive with other institutions of higher education in our service region and of similar Carnegie classification.  Furthermore, the instrument has and will support the recruitment of new faculty and graduate students and the education of hundreds of undergraduate and graduate students, some of them directly involved in projects using the instrument, while others through learning in classes that take advantage of the instrument.  In addition, the instrument has been and will continue to be utilized in outreach activities, which included laboratory tours and class demonstrations to local elementary, junior high, and high school students, and community college students aspiring to higher education and biomedical research careers.

 


Last Modified: 12/14/2022
Modified by: Luis G Villa Diaz
